===Home media=== ''The Social Network'' was released on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray]] January 11, 2011. In its first week of release, DVD sales totaled $13,470,305 and it was the number-one-sold DVD of the week.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2010/SOCIL-DVD.php |title=The Social Network – DVD Sales |work=The-Numbers.com |accessdate=February 1, 2011}}</ref> The DVD includes an [[audio commentary]] with director [[David Fincher]], and a second commentary with writer [[Aaron Sorkin]] and the cast. The Blu-ray and two-disc DVD releases include the commentaries, along with a feature length documentary, ''How Did They Ever Make a Movie of Facebook?'', featurettes, ''Angus Wall, Kirk Baxter and Ren Klyce on Post'', ''Trent Reznor, Atticus Ross and David Fincher on the Score'', ''In the Hall of the Mountain King: Reznor's First Draft'', ''[[Swarmatron]]'', ''Jeff Cronenweth and David Fincher on the Visuals'', and a Ruby Skye VIP Room: Multi-Angle Scene Breakdown feature.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://homevideo.about.com/od/dvdr6/fr/The-Social-Network-DVD-Review-a.htm |title=DVD Pick: 'The Social Network' |author=Redwine, Ivana |work=About.com |accessdate=February 1, 2011}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Box office=== During its opening weekend in the United States, the film debuted at No. 1, grossing $22.4 million in 2,771 theaters.<ref name="BoxOfficeMojo" /> The film retained the top spot in its second weekend, dropping only 31.2%,<ref name="BoxOfficeMojo" /> breaking ''[[Inception]]''{{'}}s 32.0% record as the smallest second weekend drop for any number-one film of 2010, while being the third-smallest overall behind [[Secretariat (film)|''Secretariat'']]'s 25.1% drop and [[Tooth Fairy (2010 film)|''Tooth Fairy'']]'s 28.6% drop. At the end of its theatrical run, the film grossed $97 million in the United States and $128 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $224.9 million.<ref name="BoxOfficeMojo" />
===Critical response=== On review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 96% based on 300 reviews, with an average rating of 9/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Impeccably scripted, beautifully directed, and filled with fine performances, ''The Social Network'' is a riveting, ambitious example of modern filmmaking at its finest."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_social_network |title=The Social Network (2010) |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango Media|Fandango]] |accessdate=February 24, 2017}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film holds a score of 95 out of 100, based on 42 critics, indicating "universal acclaim" and making it one of the site's highest-rated movies of all time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/the-social-network |title=The Social Network |work=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=October 3, 2010}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "B+" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name="CinemaScore">{{cite web |url=https://m.cinemascore.com |title=CinemaScore |work=cinemascore.com}}</ref>
[[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', giving it four stars and naming it the best film of the year, wrote: "David Fincher's film has the rare quality of being not only as smart as its brilliant hero, but in the same way. It is cocksure, impatient, cold, exciting and instinctively perceptive."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100929/REVIEWS/100929984 |title=Reviews, The Social Network |work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |accessdate=September 30, 2010}}</ref><!--This Roger Ebert quote looks like a misprint even though it's a direct quote from his website. It should probably read, "David Fincher's film has the rare quality of being not only as smart as its brilliant hero, but in the same way it is cocksure, impatient, cold, exciting and instinctively perceptive." – or something like that. I'll write to Roger before changing it.--> [[Peter Travers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' gave the film his first full four-star rating of the year and said: "''The Social Network'' is the movie of the year. But Fincher and Sorkin triumph by taking it further. Lacing their scathing wit with an aching sadness, they define the dark irony of the past decade."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/45905/210633 |title=The Social Network, Rolling Stone Movies, News and Reviews |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |accessdate=September 30, 2010}}</ref> ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]'' review called it "flawless" and gave it five stars.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2010/9/30/zuckerberg-facebook-social-movie |last=Leskowitz |first=Ali R. |title=Ambition and Obsession Drive Fincher's Flawless 'Social Network' |work=The Harvard Crimson |date=September 30, 2010 |accessdate=April 19, 2014}}</ref> [[Quentin Tarantino]] listed ''The Social Network'' as one of his favorite 20 movies of the year, second to ''[[Toy Story 3]]''.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/quentin-tarantinos-surprising-choices-films-67595 |title=Quentin Tarantino's Surprising Choices for Best Films of 2010 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |accessdate=January 10, 2011 |first=Kimberly |last=Nordyke}}</ref>
[[Joe Morgenstern]] in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' praised the film as exhilarating but noted: "The biographical part takes liberties with its subject. Aaron Sorkin based his screenplay on a contentious book, Ben Mezrich's ''[[The Accidental Billionaires]]'', so everything that's seen isn't necessarily to be believed."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704483004575523822326312414?mod=WSJ_LifeStyle_Lifestyle_6 |title=Social Network: Password Is Perfection |work=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=October 9, 2010 |first=Joe |last=Morgenstern |date=October 1, 2010}}</ref>
The film won Best Picture from the [[National Board of Review]], [[National Society of Film Critics]], [[New York Film Critics Circle]], and [[Los Angeles Film Critics Association]], making it only the third film in history—after ''[[Schindler's List]]'' (1993) and ''[[L.A. Confidential (film)|L.A. Confidential]]'' (1997)—to sweep the "Big Four" critics awards.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/455955/The-Social-Network/awards |title=The Social Network – Cast, Crew, Director and Awards |work=The New York Times |accessdate=March 3, 2012}}</ref> The film also won the "Hollywood Ensemble Award" from the [[Hollywood Film Awards]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.etonline.com/movies/101781_Angelina_Leo_Vote_for_Your_Faves_for_the_Hollywood_Awards/index.html |title=Angelina! Leo! Vote for Your Faves for the Hollywood Awards |work=ETOnline.com |accessdate=October 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101019175443/http://www.etonline.com/movies/101781_Angelina_Leo_Vote_for_Your_Faves_for_the_Hollywood_Awards/index.html |archivedate=October 19, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://classic.cnbc.com/id/39845137 |title='Inception' Wins Hollywood Movie Awards |work=Classic.CNBC.com |accessdate=October 26, 2010 }}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> ''The Social Network'' appeared on 78 critics' top 10 lists for 2010; of those critics 22 had the film in their number one spot.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://features.metacritic.com/features/2010/film-critic-top-ten-lists |title=The Scorecard: Critics pick the best movies of 2010 |work=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=February 2, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wCziDajr?url=http://features.metacritic.com/features/2010/film-critic-top-ten-lists/ |archivedate=February 3, 2011}}</ref>
In August 2016, ''The Social Network'' was voted the 27th-best film of the 21st century by the BBC, as voted on by 177 film critics from around the world.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20160819-the-21st-centurys-100-greatest-films?ocid=twcul |title=The 21st Century's 100 Greatest Films |work=[[BBC]] |publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]] |accessdate=September 4, 2016}}</ref>
====Top ten lists==== ''The Social Network'' appeared on over 70 critics' top-ten lists of the best films of 2010. Over a dozen publications ranked the film first in their lists, including the British film magazine ''[[Sight & Sound]]''.<ref name="2010 Film Critic Top Ten Lists"> {{cite web |url=http://features.metacritic.com/features/2010/film-critic-top-ten-lists |title=2010 Film Critic Top Ten Lists |accessdate=January 6, 2011 |work=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2010: The year in review|url=http://old.bfi.org.uk/sightandsound/polls/films-of-2010-intro.php|website=BFI | Sight & Sound|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|accessdate=7 February 2016|date=18 January 2012}}</ref> {{Div col}} * 1st – [[Peter Travers]], ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' * 1st – [[Roger Ebert]], ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' * 1st – [[Christy Lemire]], [[Associated Press]] * 1st – Andrea Grunvall, ''[[Chicago Reader]]'' * 1st – [[Owen Gleiberman]] and [[Lisa Schwarzbaum]], ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' * 1st – Betsy Sharkey and [[Kenneth Turan]], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' * 1st – Rene Rodriguez, ''[[Miami Herald]]'' * 1st – Stephen Holden, ''[[The New York Times]]'' * 1st – [[David Denby (film critic)|David Denby]], ''[[The New Yorker]]'' * 1st – [[Now (newspaper)|Now Magazine]] * 1st – Tim Robey, ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'' * 1st – Joshua Rothkopf, ''[[Time Out (magazine)#Time Out New York|Time Out New York]]'' * 1st – Ann Hornaday, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' * 1st – [[Joe Morgenstern]], ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' * 2nd – Richard Brody, ''[[The New Yorker]]'' * 2nd – [[Glenn Kenny]], ''[[MSN|MSN Movies]]'' * 2nd – Tasha Robinson, ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' * 2nd – [[Phillip French]], ''[[The Observer]]'' * 2nd – [[Todd McCarthy]] and Kirk Honeycutt, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' * 3rd – [[Richard Roeper]], ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' * 3rd – [[Stephanie Zacharek]], ''[[Movieline]]'' * 3rd – [[Anne Thompson (film critic)|Anne Thompson]], ''[[IndieWire]]'' * 3rd – Keith Phipps and Noel Murray ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' * 4th – Scott Tobias, ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' * 4th – Joe Neumaier and Elizabeth Weitzman, ''[[New York Daily News]]'' * 5th – [[Richard Corliss]], ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'' * 7th – [[Nathan Rabin]], ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' * 7th – Claudia Puig, ''[[USA Today]]'' * 7th – [[Mick LaSalle]], ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' * 8th – [[David Ansen]], ''[[Newsweek]]'' * 9th – [[James Berardinelli]], ''Reelviews'' * Top 10 (listed alphabetically, not ranked) – [[Steven Rea]], ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' * Top 10 (listed alphabetically, not ranked) – [[Dana Stevens (critic)|Dana Stevens]], ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' {{Div col end}}
===Accolades=== {{Main article|List of accolades received by The Social Network}} ''The Social Network'' won the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Drama|Best Motion Picture – Drama Golden Globe]] at the [[68th Golden Globe Awards]] on January 16, 2011.<ref name="HFPA">{{cite web |url=http://www.goldenglobes.org/nominations |title=HFPA – Nominations and Winners |accessdate=January 16, 2011 |work=GoldenGlobes.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022120719/http://www.goldenglobes.org/nominations/ |archivedate=October 22, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The film also won the awards for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Director|Best Director]], [[Golden Globe Award for Best Screenplay|Best Screenplay]], and [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Score|Best Original Score]], making it the film with the most wins of the night.<ref name="SUTGoldenGlobes">{{cite news |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2011/jan/16/social-network-has-lead-at-globes-with-3-prizes/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306035843/http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2011/jan/16/social-network-has-lead-at-globes-with-3-prizes/ |archive-date=March 6, 2016 |title='Social Network' has lead at Globes with 3 prizes |accessdate=January 16, 2011 |author=Germain, David |work=Forbes.com |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
The film was nominated for seven [[British Academy Film Awards]], including [[BAFTA Award for Best Film|Best Film]], [[BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role|Best Actor in a Leading Role]] (Jesse Eisenberg), [[BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Supporting Role|Best Actor in a Supporting Role]] (Andrew Garfield), and [[Rising Star Award, BAFTA|Rising Star Award]] (Andrew Garfield). It won three for [[BAFTA Award for Best Editing|Best Editing]], [[BAFTA Award for Best Adapted Screenplay|Adapted Screenplay]], and [[BAFTA Award for Best Direction|Best Direction]] on February 13, 2011.<ref name="BAFTA-Past-Winners&Nominees">{{cite web |url=http://www.bafta.org/awards/film/nominations/?year=2010 |title=BAFTA Past Winners and Nominees |accessdate=February 14, 2011 |work=BAFTA.org}}</ref>
''The Social Network'' received nominations for eight [[Academy Awards]]: [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]], [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]], [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography|Best Cinematography]], [[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]], [[Academy Award for Best Film Editing|Best Film Editing]], [[Academy Award for Best Original Score|Best Original Score]], [[Academy Award for Best Sound Mixing|Best Sound Mixing]], and [[Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay|Best Adapted Screenplay]].<ref name="Oscars">{{cite web |url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/83/nominees.html |title=Winners and Nominees for the 83rd Academy Awards |accessdate=March 24, 2011 |work=Oscars.org}}</ref> It won three for [[Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay|Best Adapted Screenplay]], [[Academy Award for Best Original Score|Best Original Score]], and [[Academy Award for Best Film Editing|Best Film Editing]] at the [[83rd Academy Awards]] on February 27, 2011.
===Historical accuracy=== [[File:Mark Zuckerberg at the 37th G8 Summit in Deauville 018 v1.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Facebook founder [[Mark Zuckerberg]] expressed his dissatisfaction with a film being made about him and noted that much of the film's plot was not factual]] The script was [[internet leak|leaked]] online in July 2009.<ref>{{cite web |last=McCarthy |first=Caroline |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13577_3-10282369-36.html |title=Facebook movie screenplay reportedly doesn't suck | The Social – CNET News |work=News.CNET.com |date=July 8, 2009 |accessdate=August 21, 2010}}</ref><ref>Harlow, John (2010-05-16). [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article7127721.ece "Movie depicts seamy life of Facebook boss"]. ''Timesonline.co.uk''. Retrieved September 23, 2010.</ref> In November 2009, executive producer [[Kevin Spacey]] said, "''The Social Network'' is probably going to be a lot funnier than people might expect it to be."<ref>Ditzian, Eric. (October 11, 2009). [http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2009/11/10/kevin-spacey-says-the-social-network-will-be-a-lot-funnier-than-you-think "Kevin Spacey Says 'The Social Network' Will Be 'A Lot Funnier' Than You Think"]. ''MTV.com''. Retrieved November 19, 2009.</ref> ''[[Cardinal Courier Media|The Cardinal Courier]]'' stated that the film was about "greed, obsession, unpredictability and sex" and asked "although there are over 500 million Facebook users, does this mean Facebook can become a profitable blockbuster movie?"<ref name="Surprise">{{cite news|url=http://media.www.cardinalcourieronline.com/media/storage/paper1247/news/2009/10/23/Lifestyles/Facebook.The.Movie-3812146.shtml|title=Facebook the movie?|last=Stokes|first=Jessica|date=October 27, 2009|newspaper=[[Cardinal Courier Media|Cardinal Courier Online]]|accessdate=November 21, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830165513/http://media.www.cardinalcourieronline.com/media/storage/paper1247/news/2009/10/23/Lifestyles/Facebook.The.Movie-3812146.shtml|archivedate=August 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|location=Pittsford, New York|format=[[XHTML]] 1.0 Strict - [[College Media Network]]|df=mdy-all}}<!--If the current URL fails, use this: http://www.cardinalcourieronline.com/2.13653/facebook-the-movie-1.1761527--></ref>
At the D8 conference hosted by [[Walt Mossberg|D: All Things Digital]] on June 2, 2010, host [[Kara Swisher]] told Zuckerberg she knew he was not happy with ''The Social Network'' being based on him, to which he replied, "I just wished that nobody made a movie of me while I was still alive."<ref>{{cite web |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13860_3-20006653-56.html |title=Zuckerberg in the hot seat at D8 |work=CNET.com |date=June 2, 2010 |author=Fried, Ina}}</ref> Zuckerberg stated to [[Oprah Winfrey]] that the drama and partying of the film is mostly fiction, explaining "this is my life, so I know it's not so dramatic," and that he spent most of the past six years focusing, working hard, and [[computer programming|coding]] Facebook.<ref>{{cite web |accessdate=October 9, 2010 |url=http://www.oprah.com/oprahshow/Viewers-React-to-Waiting-For-Superman/11 |title=Education for All |work=Oprah.com |date=September 24, 2010}}</ref> Speaking to an audience at [[Stanford University]], Zuckerberg stated that the film portrayed his motivations for creating Facebook inaccurately; instead of an effort to "get girls", he says he created the site because he enjoys "building things".<ref name="TheGuardian">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/oct/20/mark-zuckerberg-the-social-network |title=Mark Zuckerberg rejects his portrayal in 'The Social Network' |last=Child |first=Ben |date=October 20, 2010 |accessdate=January 15, 2011 |work=Guardian.co.uk |location=London}}</ref> However, he added that the film accurately depicted his real-life wardrobe, saying, "It's interesting the stuff that they focused on getting right—like every single shirt and fleece they had in that movie is actually a shirt or fleece that I own."<ref name="TheGuardian" />
Facebook co-founder [[Dustin Moskovitz]] called the film a "dramatization of history ... it is interesting to see my past rewritten in a way that emphasizes things that didn't matter, (like the [[Winklevoss twins|Winklevosses]], who I've still never even met and had no part in the work we did to create the site over the past 6 years) and leaves out things that really did (like the many other people in our lives at the time, who supported us in innumerable ways)".<ref name="What-Dustin-Moskovitz-Think?">Moskovitz, Dustin. [http://www.quora.com/What-does-Dustin-Moskovitz-think-of-the-Facebook-movie?q=dustin+mosko "Reply on Quora to: What does Dustin Moskovitz think of the Facebook movie?"]. ''[[Quora]]''. July 16, 2010. Retrieved February 15, 2011.</ref> According to Moskovitz: {{cquote|A lot of exciting things happened in 2004, but mostly we just worked a lot and stressed out about things; the version in the trailer seems a lot more exciting, so I'm just going to choose to remember that we drank ourselves silly and had a lot of sex with coeds. ... The plot of the book/script unabashedly attacked [Zuckerberg], but I actually felt like a lot of his positive qualities come out truthfully in the trailer (soundtrack aside). At the end of the day, they cannot help but portray him as the driven, forward-thinking genius that he is.<ref>{{cite news |first=Dustin |last=Moskovitz |title=What does Dustin Moskovitz think of the Facebook movie? |date=July 16, 2010 |url=http://www.quora.com/What-does-Dustin-Moskovitz-think-of-the-Facebook-movie |work=[[Quora]] |accessdate=July 16, 2010}}</ref> }}
Co-founder [[Eduardo Saverin]] said of the film, "[...] the movie was clearly intended to be entertainment and not a fact-based documentary."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.parcbench.com/2010/10/18/eduardo-saverin-saves-face-blogging-about-the-facebook-movie |title=Eduardo Saverin saves face blogging about ‘The Facebook Movie’ |work=Parcbench.com |date=October 18, 2010 |accessdate=April 29, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110210170104/http://www.parcbench.com/2010/10/18/eduardo-saverin-saves-face-blogging-about-the-facebook-movie/ |archivedate=February 10, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Sorkin has stated that "I don't want my fidelity to be to the truth; I want it to be to storytelling. What is the big deal about accuracy purely for accuracy's sake, and can we not have the true be the enemy of the good?"<ref>{{cite news |first=Mark |last=Harris |title=Inventing Facebook |date=September 17, 2010 |url=http://nymag.com/movies/features/68319 |work=NYMag.com |accessdate=October 9, 2010}}</ref>
Journalist [[Jeff Jarvis]] acknowledged the film was "well-crafted" but called it "the anti-social movie", objecting to Sorkin's decision to change various events and characters for dramatic effect, and dismissing it as "the story that those who resist the change society is undergoing want to see."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.buzzmachine.com/2010/09/28/the-antisocial-movie |title=The anti-social movie |author=Jarvis, Jeff |work=BuzzMachine.com |date=September 20, 2010 |accessdate=October 2, 2010}}</ref> Technology broadcaster [[Leo Laporte]] concurred, calling the film "anti-geek and [[Misogyny|misogynistic]]".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.twitter.com/leolaporte/status/26132660071 |title=@kevinmarks Spot on Kevin. I'm a fan of Sorkin, but #tsn is anti-geek and misogynistic. @jeffjarvis agrees. |author=[[Leo Laporte]] |work=[[Twitter]] |date=October 1, 2010 |accessdate=October 2, 2010}}</ref> Sorkin responded to these allegations by saying, "I was writing about a very angry and deeply misogynistic group of people".<ref name="WomanProblem">{{cite web |last=Paskin |first=Willa |title=Aaron Sorkin Would Like to Go Door-to-Door Apologizing for The Social Network’s Woman Problem |work=NYMag.com |date=October 12, 2010 |url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2010/10/aaron_sorkin_would_like_to_go.html?mid=agenda--20101012 |accessdate=January 15, 2011}}</ref>
Andrew Clark of ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote that "there's something insidious about this genre of [docudrama] scriptwriting," wondering if "a 26-year-old businessman really deserves to have his name dragged through the mud in a murky mixture of fact and imagination for the general entertainment of the movie-viewing public?" Clark added, "I'm not sure whether Mark Zuckerberg is a punk, a genius or both. But I won't be seeing ''The Social Network'' to find out."<ref>{{cite news |first=Andrew |last=Clark |title=The Social Network and docudrama dishonesty |date=September 24, 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/andrew-clark-on-america/2010/sep/23/facebook-mark-zuckerberg |work=Guardian.co.uk |location=London |accessdate=October 9, 2010}}</ref>
Several noteworthy tech journalists and bloggers voiced their opinions of how the film portrays its real-life characters. [[Mashable]] founder and CEO [[Pete Cashmore]], blogging for [[CNN]], said: "If the Facebook founder [Zuckerberg] is concerned about being represented as anything but a genius with an industrious work ethic, he can breathe a sigh of relief."<ref>{{cite news |first=Pete |last=Cashmore |title=Why Zuckerberg should like the Facebook movie |date=October 1, 2010 |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/TECH/social.media/09/30/facebook.movie.zuckerberg/index.html |work=CNNTech |accessdate=October 9, 2010}}</ref> Jessi Hempel, a technology writer for ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' who says she's known Zuckerberg "for a long time", wrote of the film: {{cquote|The real-life Zuckerberg was maniacally focused on building a web site that could potentially connect everyone on the planet...By contrast, in the film he seems more obsessed with achieving the largesse that bad boy [[Sean Parker]], an original [[Napster]] founder, portrays when he arrives to meet Zuckerberg at a New York restaurant.<ref>{{cite news |first=Jessi |last=Hempel |title=The incredibly untrue adventures of Mark Zuckerberg |date=September 24, 2010 |url=http://tech.fortune.cnn.com/2010/09/24/the-incredibly-untrue-adventures-of-mark-zuckerberg |work=Fortune.CNN.com |accessdate=October 9, 2010}}</ref>}}
[[Harvard Law School]] professor [[Lawrence Lessig]] wrote in ''[[The New Republic]]'' that Sorkin's screenplay does not acknowledge the "real villain" of the story: {{cquote|The total and absolute absurdity of the world where the engines of a federal lawsuit get cranked up to adjudicate the hurt feelings (because "our idea was stolen!") of entitled Harvard undergraduates is completely missed by Sorkin. We can't know enough from the film to know whether there was actually any substantial legal claim here. Sorkin has been upfront about the fact that there are fabrications aplenty lacing the story. But from the story as told, we certainly know enough to know that any legal system that would allow these kids to extort $65 million from the most successful business this century should be ashamed of itself. Did Zuckerberg breach his contract? Maybe, for which the damages are more like $650, not $65 million. Did he steal a trade secret? Absolutely not. Did he steal any other "property"? Absolutely not—the code for Facebook was his, and the "idea" of a social network is not a patent. It wasn't justice that gave the twins $65 million; it was the fear of a random and inefficient system of law. That system is a tax on innovation and creativity. That tax is the real villain here, not the innovator it burdened.<ref>{{cite news |first=Lawrence |last=Lessig |title=Sorkin vs. Zuckerberg |date=October 1, 2010 |url=http://www.tnr.com/print/article/books-and-arts/78081/sorkin-zuckerberg-the-social-network |work=The New Republic |accessdate=October 9, 2010}}</ref> }}
In an onstage discussion with ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' co-founder [[Arianna Huffington]], during Advertising Week 2010 in New York, Facebook's Chief Operating Officer [[Sheryl Sandberg]] said she had seen the film and it was "very Hollywood" and mainly "fiction". "In real life, he [Zuckerberg] was just sitting around with his friends in front of his computer, ordering pizza," she declared. "Who wants to go see that for two hours?"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://m.cnet.com/site?sid=cnet&pid=News.Detail&category=&topic=20018070&changeTitle=Sandberg%3A%20It's%20more%20than%20a%20'Facebook%20phone'%20-%20CNET%20News%20 |title=Sandberg: It's more than a 'Facebook phone' |author=Caroline McCarthy |work=CNET News |date=September 29, 2010 |accessdate=October 9, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100923045859/http://m.cnet.com/site?sid=cnet |archivedate=September 23, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
[[Divya Narendra]] said that he was "initially surprised" to see himself portrayed by the non-Indian actor [[Max Minghella]], but also admitted that the actor did a "good job in pushing the dialogue forward and creating a sense of urgency in what was a very frustrating period."<ref>{{cite news |last=Zhu |first=Katherine |title=Divya Narendra on being a Wildcat, ''The Social Network'' and his suit against Facebook |work=[[North by Northwestern]] |date=November 10, 2010 |url=http://www.northbynorthwestern.com/2010/11/97172/divya-narendra-on-being-a-wildcat-the-social-network-and-his-suit-against-facebook |accessdate=January 19, 2011}}</ref> ===Impact=== Since its release, ''The Social Network'' has been cited as inspiring involvement in start-ups and social media.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.firepolemarketing.com/entrepreneur-motivation |title=A Kick in the Butt from Fake Mark Zuckerberg |work=Firepole Marketing |accessdate=April 22, 2014}}</ref> [[Bob Lefsetz]] has stated that: "watching this movie makes you want to run from the theatre, grab your laptop and build your own empire,"<ref name="hardknoxlife.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.hardknoxlife.com/2010/10/07/the-social-network-will-inspire-an-entirely-new-generation-of-entrepreneurs/ |title="The Social Network" will inspire an entirely new generation of entrepreneurs |work=Hard Knox Life |accessdate=April 22, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429075607/http://www.hardknoxlife.com/2010/10/07/the-social-network-will-inspire-an-entirely-new-generation-of-entrepreneurs/ |archivedate=April 29, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> noting that ''The Social Network'' has helped fuel an emerging perception that "techies have become the new rock stars."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://socialmediatoday.com/daveknox/198444/%E2%80%9C-social-network%E2%80%9D-will-inspire-entirely-new-generation-entrepreneurs |title=The Social Network |work=socialmedia today |accessdate=April 22, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124091014/http://socialmediatoday.com/daveknox/198444/%E2%80%9C-social-network%E2%80%9D-will-inspire-entirely-new-generation-entrepreneurs |archivedate=November 24, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> This has led Dave Knox to comment that: "fifteen years from now we might just look back and realize this movie inspired our next great generation of entrepreneurs."<ref name="hardknoxlife.com"/> After seeing the movie, Zuckerberg was quoted as saying he is "interested to see what effect ''The Social Network'' has on entrepreneurship", noting that he gets "lots of messages from people who claim that they have been very much inspired... to start their own company."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mashable.com/2010/10/06/mark-zuckerbergs-take-on-the-social-network-interview/ |title=Mark Zuckerberg's Take on "The Social Network" |work=Mashable |accessdate=April 22, 2014}}</ref> Saverin echoed these sentiments, stating that the film may inspire "countless others to create and take that leap to start a new business."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/39675388 |title=Facebook Co-Founder Speaks Publicly: What I Learned From Watching "The Social Network" |work=CNBC |accessdate=April 22, 2014}}</ref> In one such instance, the co-founders of [[Wall Street Magnate]] confirmed that they were inspired to create the fantasy trading community after watching ''The Social Network''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bootcamp.com/interview.jsp?interviewId=1589 |title=Consumer friendly stock simulation: Wall Street Magnate |work=Boot Camp |accessdate=April 22, 2014}}</ref>
Following his success with the film, Sorkin became attached to another project about a technology company, writing the script for the 2015 biopic ''[[Steve Jobs (film)|Steve Jobs]]'', which used a similar format.<ref name="hollywood.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywood.com/news/movies/56803168/david-fincher-in-talks-to-direct-steve-jobs-movie-written-by-aaron-sorkin-walter-isaacson |title=All the Ways Fincher and Sorkin's Steve Jobs Biopic Will Be Just Like 'Social Network' |work=Hollywood.com |accessdate=April 22, 2014}}</ref> Another Facebook film may be produced, as the company's COO, [[Sheryl Sandberg]], has signed a deal with [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] to develop her new book ''[[Lean In|Lean In: Women, Work and the Will to Lead]]'', into a movie.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.entertainmentwise.com/news/139031/From-The-Social-Network-To-Lean-In-Facebook-COO-Sheryl-Sandberg-To-Release-Film |title=From The Social Network To Lean In: Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg To Release Film |work=Entertainmentwise.com |accessdate=April 22, 2014}}</ref>

{{short description|Russian businessman}} {{for|the Soviet Olympic sprinter|Vasily Anisimov (athlete)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Vasily Anisimov | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Vasily V. Anisimov | birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date |65|2017|05|21|df=y}}<ref name="forbes1"/> | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Russian | residence = [[Moscow]], Russia | education = | alma mater = | occupation = property developer | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | known for = | boards = | salary = | networth = US$1.49 billion (May 2017)<ref name="forbes1">{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/vasily-anisimov/ |title=Vasily Anisimov |publisher=Forbes.com |accessdate=21 May 2017}}</ref> | spouse = Galina Anisimova (divorced) | children = 4 | parents = | relations = | website = }}
'''Vasily V. Anisimov''' (born 1951/52) is a Russian [[billionaire]] businessman. In the 1990s, he owned banks and aluminium plants, sold everything in 2000, and is now a property developer.
==Early life== Gordeev has a bachelor's degree from the Alma-Ata Institute of National Economy.<ref name="forbes1"/>
==Career== From 1986 to 1989, he served as general director of a Moscow-based hardware wholesaler, Roskhoztorg. In the 1990s, he owned banks and aluminium plants - Metalloinvest. In 2000, after being sued by fellow Russian billionaire [[Mikhail Khodorkovsky]], Anisimv liquidated most of his assets.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Frik Els |url=http://www.mining.com/2012-mining-billionaires-34-vasily-anisimov-35-alexander-nesis-36-igor-zyuzin-37-patokh-chodiev-38-alijan-ibragimov-39-alexander-machkevich-40-daniel-mate-and-aristotelis-mistakidis/ |title=2012 Mining Billionaires: #34 Vasily Anisimov, #35 Alexander Nesis, #36 Igor Zyuzin, #37 Patokh Chodiev, #38 Alijan Ibragimov, #39 Alexander Machkevich, #40 Daniel Mate, #41 Aristotelis Mistakidis |publisher=MINING.com |date=15 April 2012 |accessdate=17 June 2017}}</ref> By 2004 Anismimov re-emerged as a co-owner of Metalloinvest with fellow billionaires Alisher Usmanov and Andrei Skoch.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.albawaba.com/business/secret-dealings-of-swiss-lawyer-dieter-neupert-922326#comment-form-title |title=The Secret Dealings of Swiss Lawyer Dieter Neupert |publisher=Al Bawaba |date=5 January 2017 |accessdate=17 June 2017}}</ref> From here he switched form Russian mines to realeste.<ref name="forbes1"/> His wealth comes from investments in [[Metalloinvest]] and his real estate company Coalco.<ref name="businessinsider.com">{{cite web|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/the-most-eligible-russian-billionaires-in-the-world-2016-7/#t-10-vasily-anisimov-3|title=The 11 richest Russian men who are still single|publisher=}}</ref>
He is a friend of [[Arkady Rotenberg]], and is the head of the Russian Judo Federation.<ref name="therealdeal1">{{cite web|last=Putzier |first=Konrad |url=https://therealdeal.com/2015/05/13/russian-oligarchs-ex-pays-20m-for-carlton-house-co-op/ |title=Carlton House | Galina Anisimova | Vasily Anisimov |publisher=Therealdeal.com |date=13 May 2015 |accessdate=21 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="businessinsider.com"/>
==Personal life== Anisimov was married to Galina Anisimova, and has four children.<ref name="therealdeal1"/><ref name="forbes1"/> Their daughter, Galina, was murdered with her husband, Alexander Nalimov, both found "bound and killed execution-style," in their [[Ekaterinburg]] home in 2000.<ref>[http://old.themoscowtimes.com/sitemap/free/2000/4/article/metals-magnates-in-85b-merger/264102.html McChesney, Andrew] "Metals Magnates In $8.5B Merger", ''The Moscow Times'', April 18, 2000. Retrieved October 16, 2018.</ref><ref>[http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/people/features/9873/index2.html Eaton, Pheobe] "How Much Is That In Rubles?", ''New York'', June 2012. Retrieved October 16, 2018.</ref> Another daughter, Galina's half-sister, Anna Anisimova, is a socialite and ex-model who has been called the "Russian-American Paris Hilton".<ref name="therealdeal1"/>
He lives in [[Moscow]], Russia,<ref name="forbes1"/> and sometimes in [[New York City|New York]].
